instruction: What is the mental lexicon and how does it relate to associative knowledge?
expected_response:
The mental lexicon is defined as a repository of knowledge suited for the acquisition, processing, and use of all information that can be expressed via language [1]. A key aspect of the mental lexicon is associative knowledge, which interfaces with semantic and autobiographical memory, mapping similarities between conceptual representations and driving recall and the processing of conceptual information [1].

Associative knowledge, a cognitive subsystem within the mental lexicon, plays a crucial role in how individuals structure their understanding of the external world. It can be represented as networks of concepts, allowing for the investigation of various cognitive processes such as word learning (Hills et al., 2009; Stella et al., 2017), creativity (Kenett and Faust, 2019; Stella and Kenett, 2019), and domain-specific competence levels (Tyumeneva et al., 2017; Siew, 2020) [1].

These networks of concepts can be further analyzed using graph theory and network analytical techniques. Behavioural forma mentis networks (BFMNs), which model how individuals structure their associative knowledge about the external world by capturing associations between ideas and attributing valence to them, are a key tool in this analysis [1]. BFMNs represent free association memory recall patterns, reflecting both cognitive and affective perspectives on conceptual associations. For instance, positive concepts might tend to link with each other, while negative concepts might contrast with positive ones [1].

Thus, the mental lexicon and associative knowledge are integral to understanding how individuals process and utilize language, as well as their broader cognitive functions and emotional responses [1].

[1] Section: 1. Introduction | Page 2
vulner- ability and maintenance factor in models of functioning for a variety of anxiety disorders (Kashdan et al., 2006; Dymond, 2019; Van Den Hout et al., 2014). Experiential avoidance can also have negative repercussions on sustaining math anxiety (Beilock et al., 2010), but how could it be measured and captured in students dealing with math learning? Methods from cognitive network science can provide a deeper understanding of stu- dents‚Äô thought processes (D√≥czi, 2019), since mental representations of knowledge are part of a much more complex system, known as the mental lexicon. The mental lexicon can be defined as a repository of knowledge suited for the acquisition, processing, and use of all information that can be expressed via language (D√≥czi, 2019). A key aspect of the mental lexicon is associative knowledge, a cognitive subsystem that interfaces with semantic and autobiographical memory, mapping similarities between conceptual repre- sentations, and driving recall, as well as the processing of conceptual information (Collins and Loftus, 1975; Laiacona et al., 1993; Stella et al., 2024). Numerous cognitive processes, such as word learning (Hills et al., 2009; Stella et al., 2017), creativity (Kenett and Faust, 2019; Stella and Kenett, 2019), and domain-specific competence levels (Tyumeneva et al., 2017; Siew, 2020), among many others, can all be investigated by representing associative knowledge as a network of concepts. Networks of concepts can then be further analysed quantitatively using graph theory and network analytical techniques (Siew et al., 2019b). Behavioural forma mentis networks (BFMNs) are complex networks modelling how individuals structure their associative knowledge about the external world (Stella and Kenett, 2019; Stella and Zaytseva, 2020). BFMNs owe their name to their nature as proxies of someone‚Äôs mindset (Smeets et al. (2006); "forma mentis" stands for mindset in Latin), captured in terms of associating ideas/concepts and attributing valence to them. The strength of BFMNs lies in their ability to represent knowledge structures via mem- ory recall patterns, also known as free associations (De Deyne et al., 2013), and going beyond the necessity of defining specific associative constraints. Free associations can be represented as multidimensional links of memory recall patterns between ideas, combin- ing semantic, syntactic, phonological, but also visual, experiential or simply co-occurring features of conceptual associations in someone‚Äôs cognitive memory (Citraro et al., 2023). BFMNs use free associations to structure how individuals‚Äô or groups‚Äô associative knowl- edge is shaped around key target ideas (e. g. cues that elicit someone‚Äôs memory and start the creation of links between cues and responses). On top of this cognitive dimension, BFMNs also encapsulate an affective perspective, according to whether individuals/groups perceive their recalled ideas positively, negatively or neutrally valenced. Consequently, af- fective perceptions in terms of conceptual valence can alter the quality of free association structures of conceptual associations. For example, positive concepts might tend to link with each other, while a negative concept might be contrasted with other positive ideas. BFMNs have been used in the past to assess negative attitudes towards science among high school students and researchers (Stella and Kenett, 2019), and can also be employed at different times to assess changes in individual or group-level mindsets over time (Stella and Zaytseva, 2020). BFMNs have also been applied in the emerging field of machine psychology (i. e. a field lying at the intersection of psychology and computer science) to investigate the mindsets of Large Language Models (LLMs; Abramski et al. (2023)). As artificial intelligences (AIs) learn conceptual associations from vast amounts of human texts, LLMs can mirror 3

instruction: Summarize the key findings related to math anxiety in the paper.
expected_response: The key findings suggest that math anxiety is rooted not only in emotional responses but also in the affective and structural organization of semantic memory. A more interconnected and negatively valenced representation of 'anxiety' appears to mirror stronger math-related fears, which aligns with mechanisms such as rumination, which depletes working memory and heightens math anxiety (Section: 4. Experiment 2 | Page 11). The analysis also revealed that GPT-4o simulated students with higher math anxiety tended to establish broader associative connections to 'anxiety' ‚Äî making it a more central concept in their semantic networks ‚Äî while concurrently attributing more negative emotional valence to 'math' (Section: 5.4.2. Linear Regressions Analysis | Page 20).

rag.prompt:
You are a research paper assistant. Answer the question using the provided context. Do not fabricate citations. If the answer is not in the context, say you don't know.

Context:
[1] Section: 1. Introduction | Page 2
1. Introduction Math anxiety is characterised by feelings of apprehension and heightened physiological responses when individuals encounter math-related situations (Hembree, 1990; Richardson and Suinn, 1972). This includes exposure to evaluative contexts involving mathematical ability (e. g. taking a math exam), the need to handle numbers in everyday scenarios (e. g. splitting bills), and the passive observation of math-related activities (e. g. watching someone solve a problem Hunt et al. (2011)). Although suffering from math anxiety may not meet the diagnostic criteria of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Dis- orders (American Psychiatric Association, 2022) for an anxiety disorder, evidence shows that individuals who suffer from math anxiety experience a significant impairment in their well-being, as well as in their academic success (Ashcraft, 2002; Wu et al., 2014; Chang and Beilock, 2016; Gabriel et al., 2020; Caviola et al., 2022). Furthermore, math anxiety should be distinguished from anxiety related to other STEM (Science, Technological, En- gineering, and Mathematics) subjects (Paechter et al., 2017), or from general test anxiety (Zeidner, 2007; Cassady and Johnson, 2002). Math anxiety manifests in both cognitive and emotional dimensions: individuals ex- perience impairment in working memory (Beilock et al., 2007; Macher et al., 2012), and report feelings of considerable tension and worry. Reducing the maximum load of working memory means that math anxiety can drastically reduce the ability for individuals to load and manipulate symbols, competencies and knowledge, negatively impacting their math performance (Stella, 2022). Besides this, as a consequence of math anxiety, individuals adopt safety-seeking behaviours, such as actions that could help them avoid feared stimuli or outcomes (Cuming et al., 2009; Gangemi et al., 2012). Since its early days (Mowrer, 1960), psychology has defined avoidance as a behavioural response to external stimuli that produce fear and anxiety, aimed at reducing the experience of fear through negative reinforcement, which can be intrinsically rewarding. Internal stimuli, such as thoughts and emotions, contribute to a prolonged anxious response that prevents the extinction of the anxiety and reinforces the emotion itself (Hayes et al., 1996). Although this principle originates from research on general anxiety disorders, it is also relevant to math anxiety. In the context of math anxiety, avoidance behaviour manifests as a reluctance to engage with math tasks, which prevents cognitive reprocessing and deepening of mathematical understanding. By avoiding math-related tasks, students fail to strengthen, extend, and nuance their mathematical concepts through continuous processing, leading to a cycle of avoidance that hinders their mathematical development (Hembree, 1990). However, when anxiety leads an individual to experiential avoidance, preventing con- stant exposure to anxiety-inducing information, mental representations remain static, hindering the development of cognitive complexity (i. e. the creation of fewer associations with the target of avoidance) and strengthening the negative emotional aspect (i. e. to perceiving the target of avoidance as more negative than it is). This triggers various cognitive biases, common in both individuals who suffer from anxiety and those who do not (Van Den Hout et al., 2014). For example, the "behaviour as information" bias leads individuals to believe that "If I avoid, then there is a danger", prompting safety-seeking behaviours that hinder further exposure to the feared stimulus, and create a cascading effect (Gangemi et al., 2012). Another type of bias is emotional reasoning, through which individuals tend to use their emotions as significant information about external events, even when the emotion is not generated by the situation being evaluated (Arntz et al., 1995; Gangemi et al., 2012). Math anxiety can also be transmitted and reinforce gender stereotypes, as demonstrated by the work of Beilock et al. (2010), which highlighted that 2 female teachers‚Äô math anxiety can reinforce gender stereotypes in female students, but not in male students. Nowadays, experiential avoidance (Hayes et al., 1996) is the primary target of standard interventions for anxiety disorders, and it is considered both a vulner- ability and maintenance factor in models of functioning for a variety of anxiety disorders (Kashdan et al., 2006; Dymond, 2019; Van Den Hout et al., 2014). Experiential avoidance can also have negative repercussions on sustaining math anxiety (Beilock et al., 2010), but how could it be measured and captured in students dealing with math learning? Methods from cognitive network science can provide a deeper understanding of stu- dents‚Äô thought processes (D√≥czi, 2019), since mental representations of knowledge are part of a much more complex system, known as the mental lexicon. The mental lexicon can be defined as a repository of knowledge suited for the acquisition, processing, and use of all information that can be expressed via language (D√≥czi, 2019).

Reducing the maximum load of working memory means that math anxiety can drastically reduce the ability for individuals to load and manipulate symbols, competencies and knowledge, negatively impacting their math performance (Stella, 2022). Besides this, as a consequence of math anxiety, individuals adopt safety-seeking behaviours, such as actions that could help them avoid feared stimuli or outcomes (Cuming et al., 2009; Gangemi et al., 2012). Since its early days (Mowrer, 1960), psychology has defined avoidance as a behavioural response to external stimuli that produce fear and anxiety, aimed at reducing the experience of fear through negative reinforcement, which can be intrinsically rewarding. Internal stimuli, such as thoughts and emotions, contribute to a prolonged anxious response that prevents the extinction of the anxiety and reinforces the emotion itself (Hayes et al., 1996). Although this principle originates from research on general anxiety disorders, it is also relevant to math anxiety. In the context of math anxiety, avoidance behaviour manifests as a reluctance to engage with math tasks, which prevents cognitive reprocessing and deepening of mathematical understanding. By avoiding math-related tasks, students fail to strengthen, extend, and nuance their mathematical concepts through continuous processing, leading to a cycle of avoidance that hinders their mathematical development (Hembree, 1990). However, when anxiety leads an individual to experiential avoidance, preventing con- stant exposure to anxiety-inducing information, mental representations remain static, hindering the development of cognitive complexity (i. e. the creation of fewer associations with the target of avoidance) and strengthening the negative emotional aspect (i. e. to perceiving the target of avoidance as more negative than it is). This triggers various cognitive biases, common in both individuals who suffer from anxiety and those who do not (Van Den Hout et al., 2014). For example, the "behaviour as information" bias leads individuals to believe that "If I avoid, then there is a danger", prompting safety-seeking behaviours that hinder further exposure to the feared stimulus, and create a cascading effect (Gangemi et al., 2012). Another type of bias is emotional reasoning, through which individuals tend to use their emotions as significant information about external events, even when the emotion is not generated by the situation being evaluated (Arntz et al., 1995; Gangemi et al., 2012). Math anxiety can also be transmitted and reinforce gender stereotypes, as demonstrated by the work of Beilock et al. (2010), which highlighted that 2 female teachers‚Äô math anxiety can reinforce gender stereotypes in female students, but not in male students. Nowadays, experiential avoidance (Hayes et al., 1996) is the primary target of standard interventions for anxiety disorders, and it is considered both a vulner- ability and maintenance factor in models of functioning for a variety of anxiety disorders (Kashdan et al., 2006; Dymond, 2019; Van Den Hout et al., 2014). Experiential avoidance can also have negative repercussions on sustaining math anxiety (Beilock et al., 2010), but how could it be measured and captured in students dealing with math learning? Methods from cognitive network science can provide a deeper understanding of stu- dents‚Äô thought processes (D√≥czi, 2019), since mental representations of knowledge are part of a much more complex system, known as the mental lexicon. The mental lexicon can be defined as a repository of knowledge suited for the acquisition, processing, and use of all information that can be expressed via language (D√≥czi, 2019).

[2] Section: 75 undergraduate students from the Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science | Page 8
impair cognitive functioning and problem-solving abilities, emphasising the detrimental effects of negative emotional states on mathematical performance. This is supported by Chang and Beilock (2016), who further elucidated how math anxiety disrupts working memory and increases avoidance behaviour in math-related tasks. Additionally, Caviola et al. (2022) provided insights into how math anxiety affects students‚Äô performance and attitudes, finding that high levels of math anxiety are associ- ated with poorer performance and more negative associations with mathematical tasks. Their work underscores the need to explore how these negative associations are formed and maintained within cognitive networks. While these studies have significantly advanced our understanding of math anxiety and its consequences, there remains a need for further exploration into how cognitive networks, specifically related to math, are influenced by varying levels of anxiety. This experiment aims to investigate the characteristics of cognitive networks in a sample of un- dergraduate psychology students by exploring how perceptions and associations related to math vary in relation to levels of math anxiety. By employing a free association task to map cognitive networks, this research uncovers individual and group differences in the perception and association of mathematical ideas. The goal is to deepen our under- standing of the psychological mechanisms underlying math anxiety and its cognitive and emotional implications, thereby contributing valuable insights into the interplay between anxiety, cognition, and academic performance. 3. 2. Participants and Materials 75 undergraduate students from the Department of Psychology and Cognitive Science at the University of Trento (Italy) were recruited through convenience sampling using the department‚Äôs social media channels and word of mouth. All participants were adults and native Italian speakers. The protocol was approved by the Human Research Ethics Committee of the University of South Australia (ID: 205244) and complied with the Declaration of Helsinki. Participants signed an informed consent and did not receive any compensation for their participation. We cleaned the data, removing all the participants who did not provide any associa- tions for the cue words "math" and "anxiety", which were fundamental for the network analysis. We also excluded participants with more than 1/3 of the data missing. In the end, only 70 participants out of the initial 75 were considered for the analysis. Each participant followed the procedure described in the Methods Section. In partic- ular, for Experiment 1, we selected 40 words as stimuli (i. e. cue words), which can be clustered into 4 groups, consisting of words related to: 1. STEM and Academic Disciplines 2. Psychology and Mental Health 3. Academic Evaluation 4. Personal Attitude The 40 cue words of the current experiment are reported in Table A. 1. As for the analyses performed to obtain the results of Experiment 1, we refer to the Analysis Section. 3. 3. Results In Table 2 we report the statistics of the main network features described in Section Behavioural forma mentis networks. There we see that the degree of "math" had a mean of 6. 53 (SD = 1. 21), while the degree of "anxiety" had a mean of 6. 29 (SD = 8

[3] Section: 2. Methods | Page 5
2. Methods 2. 1. Materials The first three experiments share the same methodology in terms of analysis and procedure, while they differ in the participant sample and materials used. In all the participant samples, each participant (either human or GPT-simulated) had to perform the following tasks: ‚Ä¢ Completion of the MAS-IT questionnaire. The Mathematics Anxiety Scale‚ÄìIT is the Italian translated scale of the MAS-UK questionnaire (Hunt et al., 2011) and has been validated in an Italian undergraduate population to assess math anxiety (Franchino et al., 2025). The factors originally identified by the MAS-UK, which are considered in the current study, are the following: 1. Evaluation MA (Math Anxiety), which encompasses anxiety associated with the evaluation of mathematical ability, often in formal academic settings (e. g. taking a math exam, answering a question in front of a class). 2. Everyday/Social MA, which includes anxiety experienced in everyday situa- tions involving math, often with social implications (e. g. calculating change, splitting bills, remembering phone numbers). 3. Passive Observation MA, which refers to anxiety triggered by the passive obser- vation of math-related activities, even without direct participation (e. g. watch- ing someone solve a problem, listening to a math class) (Hunt et al., 2011). Participants were asked to rate their anxiety level on a 5-point Likert scale, ranging from 1 ("not anxious at all") to 5 ("very anxious"), facilitating a comprehensive, yet approximate quantification of math anxiety levels as expressed by individuals. All the original and translated items of the MAS questionnaire can be found in Table A. 3. ‚Ä¢ Performance of a free association task. Different cue words were selected as stimuli, to which participants had to associate the first three words that came to their mind when reading them. Participants were instructed to perform the free association task as quickly as possible to preserve the spontaneity and effectiveness of the free association method (De Deyne et al., 2013). For the same reason, if a participant was unable to provide one or more associations, they were allowed to leave those responses blank. ‚Ä¢ Valence attribution task. For all the words provided in the free association task and the cue words (i. e. if a participant did not leave any association blank, the total was of 160 words), participants had to rate their emotional valence, using a Likert scale ranging from 1 ("very negative") to 5 ("very positive"), with neutrality being represented by a score of 3. For this task, no timing instruction was given. For the human participant samples, each participant sat in front of a computer, where they were first asked to complete an informed consent form outlining key information about privacy and data protection. The entire experiment lasted approximately 40 minutes. As for the GPT simulated students, the model was prompted to impersonate an under- graduate psychology student, and consequently, it generated the answers to the different tasks, coherently with its personification. All the details of this process will be described in Section Methods. 5

[4] Section: 3.3.1. Correlations Analysis | Page 9
1. 91), meaning that both "math" and "anxiety" are strongly connected to other words in students‚Äô BFMNs. The slightly higher degree for "math" suggests that it is linked to a wider range of concepts, while the strong connections to "anxiety" may reflect how emotionally important or present it is in students‚Äô minds. The closeness centrality of the word "math" had a mean of 0. 09 (SD = 0. 05), while the closeness centrality of the word "anxiety" had a mean of 0. 08 (SD = 0. 06) (cf. Table 2). Both "math" and "anxiety" are equally central within the students‚Äô BFMNs, meaning that these two concepts were just as easily reachable from other ideas in the network, reflecting their overall importance or accessibility in students‚Äô thinking. Furthermore, in Table 3, one can find the descriptive statistics of the three math anxiety factors and the total math anxiety. 3. 3. 1. Correlations Analysis The correlograms in Figure 1 examine the interrelationships among the math anxiety and network measures. Bivariate relationships between variables were inspected through zero-order Pearson‚Äôs correlations, with significance level fixed to Œ± = . 05 (N = 70). Look- Figure 1: Correlogram Experiment 1. The valence, degree and closeness centrality (CC) for the nodes "anxiety" and "math" are reported, along with the factors of MA: Evaluation, Everyday/Social (Social) and Passive Observation (Observation), together with the Total MA. ing at Figure 1, one can observe a persistent trend in the significant correlations that were found for each math anxiety factor and its totality. Specifically, across all math anx- iety dimensions, significant correlations emerged with the network features of the node 9

The mental lexicon can be defined as a repository of knowledge suited for the acquisition, processing, and use of all information that can be expressed via language (D√≥czi, 2019).

While these studies have significantly advanced our understanding of math anxiety and its consequences, there remains a need for further exploration into how cognitive networks, specifically related to math, are influenced by varying levels of anxiety. This experiment aims to investigate the characteristics of cognitive networks in a sample of un- dergraduate psychology students by exploring how perceptions and associations related to math vary in relation to levels of math anxiety. By employing a free association task to map cognitive networks, this research uncovers individual and group differences in the perception and association of mathematical ideas. The goal is to deepen our under- standing of the psychological mechanisms underlying math anxiety and its cognitive and emotional implications, thereby contributing valuable insights into the interplay between anxiety, cognition, and academic performance. 3. 2. All participants were adults and native Italian speakers. The protocol was approved by the Human Research Ethics Committee of the University of South Australia (ID: 205244) and complied with the Declaration of Helsinki. Participants signed an informed consent and did not receive any compensation for their participation. We cleaned the data, removing all the participants who did not provide any associa- tions for the cue words "math" and "anxiety", which were fundamental for the network analysis. We also excluded participants with more than 1/3 of the data missing. In the end, only 70 participants out of the initial 75 were considered for the analysis. Each participant followed the procedure described in the Methods Section. retrieved.text: 2. Methods 2. 1. Materials The first three experiments share the same methodology in terms of analysis and procedure, while they differ in the participant sample and materials used. In all the participant samples, each participant (either human or GPT-simulated) had to perform the following tasks: ‚Ä¢ Completion of the MAS-IT questionnaire. The Mathematics Anxiety Scale‚ÄìIT is the Italian translated scale of the MAS-UK questionnaire (Hunt et al., 2011) and has been validated in an Italian undergraduate population to assess math anxiety (Franchino et al., 2025). The factors originally identified by the MAS-UK, which are considered in the current study, are the following: 1. Evaluation MA (Math Anxiety), which encompasses anxiety associated with the evaluation of mathematical ability, often in formal academic settings (e. g. taking a math exam, answering a question in front of a class). 2. Everyday/Social MA, which includes anxiety experienced in everyday situa- tions involving math, often with social implications (e. g. calculating change, splitting bills, remembering phone numbers). 3. Passive Observation MA, which refers to anxiety triggered by the passive obser- vation of math-related activities, even without direct participation (e. g. watch- ing someone solve a problem, listening to a math class) (Hunt et al., 2011). Participants were asked to rate their anxiety level on a 5-point Likert scale, ranging from 1 ("not anxious at all") to 5 ("very anxious"), facilitating a comprehensive, yet approximate quantification of math anxiety levels as expressed by individuals. All the original and translated items of the MAS questionnaire can be found in Table A. 3. ‚Ä¢ Performance of a free association task. Different cue words were selected as stimuli, to which participants had to associate the first three words that came to their mind when reading them. Participants were instructed to perform the free association task as quickly as possible to preserve the spontaneity and effectiveness of the free association method (De Deyne et al., 2013). For the same reason, if a participant was unable to provide one or more associations, they were allowed to leave those responses blank. ‚Ä¢ Valence attribution task. For all the words provided in the free association task and the cue words (i. e. if a participant did not leave any association blank, the total was of 160 words), participants had to rate their emotional valence, using a Likert scale ranging from 1 ("very negative") to 5 ("very positive"), with neutrality being represented by a score of 3. For this task, no timing instruction was given. For the human participant samples, each participant sat in front of a computer, where they were first asked to complete an informed consent form outlining key information about privacy and data protection. The entire experiment lasted approximately 40 minutes. As for the GPT simulated students, the model was prompted to impersonate an under- graduate psychology student, and consequently, it generated the answers to the different tasks, coherently with its personification. All the details of this process will be described in Section Methods. 5

The slightly higher degree for "math" suggests that it is linked to a wider range of concepts, while the strong connections to "anxiety" may reflect how emotionally important or present it is in students‚Äô minds. The closeness centrality of the word "math" had a mean of 0. 09 (SD = 0. 05), while the closeness centrality of the word "anxiety" had a mean of 0. 08 (SD = 0. 06) (cf. Table 2). Both "math" and "anxiety" are equally central within the students‚Äô BFMNs, meaning that these two concepts were just as easily reachable from other ideas in the network, reflecting their overall importance or accessibility in students‚Äô thinking. Furthermore, in Table 3, one can find the descriptive statistics of the three math anxiety factors and the total math anxiety. 3. 3. 1. generator_metadata.instruction: Summarize the key findings related to math anxiety in the paper.
generator_metadata.response: The key findings suggest that math anxiety is rooted not only in emotional responses but also in the affective and structural organization of semantic memory. A more interconnected and negatively valenced representation of 'anxiety' appears to mirror stronger math-related fears, which aligns with mechanisms such as rumination, which depletes working memory and heightens math anxiety (Section: 4. Experiment 2 | Page 11). The analysis also revealed that GPT-4o simulated students with higher math anxiety tended to establish broader associative connections to 'anxiety' ‚Äî making it a more central concept in their semantic networks ‚Äî while concurrently attributing more negative emotional valence to 'math' (Section: 5.4.2. Linear Regressions Analysis | Page 20).

instruction: Identify the source of the information on how experiential avoidance contributes to math anxiety.
expected_response: Experiential avoidance can have negative repercussions on sustaining math anxiety [1].

rag.prompt:
You are a research paper assistant. Answer the question using the provided context. Cite the sources inline as [#] based on the order of the snippets. If the answer is not in the context, say you don't know. Use the numbered excerpts as explicit evidence. When more than one excerpt is relevant, cite each distinct snippet at least once using its [#] marker. Write complete sentences grounded in the excerpt content, and avoid recycling the same citation for unrelated statements or fabricating references.

Context:
[1] Section: 1. Introduction | Page 2
1. Introduction Math anxiety is characterised by feelings of apprehension and heightened physiological responses when individuals encounter math-related situations (Hembree, 1990; Richardson and Suinn, 1972). This includes exposure to evaluative contexts involving mathematical ability (e. g. taking a math exam), the need to handle numbers in everyday scenarios (e. g. splitting bills), and the passive observation of math-related activities (e. g. watching someone solve a problem Hunt et al. (2011)). Although suffering from math anxiety may not meet the diagnostic criteria of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Dis- orders (American Psychiatric Association, 2022) for an anxiety disorder, evidence shows that individuals who suffer from math anxiety experience a significant impairment in their well-being, as well as in their academic success (Ashcraft, 2002; Wu et al., 2014; Chang and Beilock, 2016; Gabriel et al., 2020; Caviola et al., 2022). Furthermore, math anxiety should be distinguished from anxiety related to other STEM (Science, Technological, En- gineering, and Mathematics) subjects (Paechter et al., 2017), or from general test anxiety (Zeidner, 2007; Cassady and Johnson, 2002). Math anxiety manifests in both cognitive and emotional dimensions: individuals ex- perience impairment in working memory (Beilock et al., 2007; Macher et al., 2012), and report feelings of considerable tension and worry. Reducing the maximum load of working memory means that math anxiety can drastically reduce the ability for individuals to load and manipulate symbols, competencies and knowledge, negatively impacting their math performance (Stella, 2022). Besides this, as a consequence of math anxiety, individuals adopt safety-seeking behaviours, such as actions that could help them avoid feared stimuli or outcomes (Cuming et al., 2009; Gangemi et al., 2012). Since its early days (Mowrer, 1960), psychology has defined avoidance as a behavioural response to external stimuli that produce fear and anxiety, aimed at reducing the experience of fear through negative reinforcement, which can be intrinsically rewarding. Internal stimuli, such as thoughts and emotions, contribute to a prolonged anxious response that prevents the extinction of the anxiety and reinforces the emotion itself (Hayes et al., 1996). Although this principle originates from research on general anxiety disorders, it is also relevant to math anxiety. In the context of math anxiety, avoidance behaviour manifests as a reluctance to engage with math tasks, which prevents cognitive reprocessing and deepening of mathematical understanding. By avoiding math-related tasks, students fail to strengthen, extend, and nuance their mathematical concepts through continuous processing, leading to a cycle of avoidance that hinders their mathematical development (Hembree, 1990). However, when anxiety leads an individual to experiential avoidance, preventing con- stant exposure to anxiety-inducing information, mental representations remain static, hindering the development of cognitive complexity (i. e. the creation of fewer associations with the target of avoidance) and strengthening the negative emotional aspect (i. e. to perceiving the target of avoidance as more negative than it is). This triggers various cognitive biases, common in both individuals who suffer from anxiety and those who do not (Van Den Hout et al., 2014). For example, the "behaviour as information" bias leads individuals to believe that "If I avoid, then there is a danger", prompting safety-seeking behaviours that hinder further exposure to the feared stimulus, and create a cascading effect (Gangemi et al., 2012). Another type of bias is emotional reasoning, through which individuals tend to use their emotions as significant information about external events, even when the emotion is not generated by the situation being evaluated (Arntz et al., 1995; Gangemi et al., 2012). Math anxiety can also be transmitted and reinforce gender stereotypes, as demonstrated by the work of Beilock et al. (2010), which highlighted that 2 female teachers‚Äô math anxiety can reinforce gender stereotypes in female students, but not in male students. Nowadays, experiential avoidance (Hayes et al., 1996) is the primary target of standard interventions for anxiety disorders, and it is considered both a vulner- ability and maintenance factor in models of functioning for a variety of anxiety disorders (Kashdan et al., 2006; Dymond, 2019; Van Den Hout et al., 2014). Experiential avoidance can also have negative repercussions on sustaining math anxiety (Beilock et al., 2010), but how could it be measured and captured in students dealing with math learning? Methods from cognitive network science can provide a deeper understanding of stu- dents‚Äô thought processes (D√≥czi, 2019), since mental representations of knowledge are part of a much more complex system, known as the mental lexicon. The mental lexicon can be defined as a repository of knowledge suited for the acquisition, processing, and use of all information that can be expressed via language (D√≥czi, 2019).

For example, the "behaviour as information" bias leads individuals to believe that "If I avoid, then there is a danger", prompting safety-seeking behaviours that hinder further exposure to the feared stimulus, and create a cascading effect (Gangemi et al., 2012). Another type of bias is emotional reasoning, through which individuals tend to use their emotions as significant information about external events, even when the emotion is not generated by the situation being evaluated (Arntz et al., 1995; Gangemi et al., 2012). Math anxiety can also be transmitted and reinforce gender stereotypes, as demonstrated by the work of Beilock et al. (2010), which highlighted that 2 female teachers‚Äô math anxiety can reinforce gender stereotypes in female students, but not in male students. Nowadays, experiential avoidance (Hayes et al., 1996) is the primary target of standard interventions for anxiety disorders, and it is considered both a vulner- ability and maintenance factor in models of functioning for a variety of anxiety disorders (Kashdan et al., 2006; Dymond, 2019; Van Den Hout et al., 2014). Experiential avoidance can also have negative repercussions on sustaining math anxiety (Beilock et al., 2010), but how could it be measured and captured in students dealing with math learning? Methods from cognitive network science can provide a deeper understanding of stu- dents‚Äô thought processes (D√≥czi, 2019), since mental representations of knowledge are part of a much more complex system, known as the mental lexicon. The mental lexicon can be defined as a repository of knowledge suited for the acquisition, processing, and use of all information that can be expressed via language (D√≥czi, 2019).

[1] Section: 1. Introduction | Page 2
1. Introduction Math anxiety is characterised by feelings of apprehension and heightened physiological responses when individuals encounter math-related situations (Hembree, 1990; Richardson and Suinn, 1972). This includes exposure to evaluative contexts involving mathematical ability (e. g. taking a math exam), the need to handle numbers in everyday scenarios (e. g. splitting bills), and the passive observation of math-related activities (e. g. watching someone solve a problem Hunt et al. (2011)). Although suffering from math anxiety may not meet the diagnostic criteria of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Dis- orders (American Psychiatric Association, 2022) for an anxiety disorder, evidence shows that individuals who suffer from math anxiety experience a significant impairment in their well-being, as well as in their academic success (Ashcraft, 2002; Wu et al., 2014; Chang and Beilock, 2016; Gabriel et al., 2020; Caviola et al., 2022). Furthermore, math anxiety should be distinguished from anxiety related to other STEM (Science, Technological, En- gineering, and Mathematics) subjects (Paechter et al., 2017), or from general test anxiety (Zeidner, 2007; Cassady and Johnson, 2002). Math anxiety manifests in both cognitive and emotional dimensions: individuals ex- perience impairment in working memory (Beilock et al., 2007; Macher et al., 2012), and report feelings of considerable tension and worry. Reducing the maximum load of working memory means that math anxiety can drastically reduce the ability for individuals to load and manipulate symbols, competencies and knowledge, negatively impacting their math performance (Stella, 2022). Besides this, as a consequence of math anxiety, individuals adopt safety-seeking behaviours, such as actions that could help them avoid feared stimuli or outcomes (Cuming et al., 2009; Gangemi et al., 2012). Since its early days (Mowrer, 1960), psychology has defined avoidance as a behavioural response to external stimuli that produce fear and anxiety, aimed at reducing the experience of fear through negative reinforcement, which can be intrinsically rewarding. Internal stimuli, such as thoughts and emotions, contribute to a prolonged anxious response that prevents the extinction of the anxiety and reinforces the emotion itself (Hayes et al., 1996). Although this principle originates from research on general anxiety disorders, it is also relevant to math anxiety. In the context of math anxiety, avoidance behaviour manifests as a reluctance to engage with math tasks, which prevents cognitive reprocessing and deepening of mathematical understanding. By avoiding math-related tasks, students fail to strengthen, extend, and nuance their mathematical concepts through continuous processing, leading to a cycle of avoidance that hinders their mathematical development (Hembree, 1990). However, when anxiety leads an individual to experiential avoidance, preventing con- stant exposure to anxiety-inducing information, mental representations remain static, hindering the development of cognitive complexity (i. e. the creation of fewer associations with the target of avoidance) and strengthening the negative emotional aspect (i. e. to perceiving the target of avoidance as more negative than it is). This triggers various cognitive biases, common in both individuals who suffer from anxiety and those who do not (Van Den Hout et al., 2014). For example, the "behaviour as information" bias leads individuals to believe that "If I avoid, then there is a danger", prompting safety-seeking behaviours that hinder further exposure to the feared stimulus, and create a cascading effect (Gangemi et al., 2012). Another type of bias is emotional reasoning, through which individuals tend to use their emotions as significant information about external events, even when the emotion is not generated by the situation being evaluated (Arntz et al., 1995; Gangemi et al., 2012). Math anxiety can also be transmitted and reinforce gender stereotypes, as demonstrated by the work of Beilock et al. (2010), which highlighted that 2 female teachers‚Äô math anxiety can reinforce gender stereotypes in female students, but not in male students. Nowadays, experiential avoidance (Hayes et al., 1996) is the primary target of standard interventions for anxiety disorders, and it is considered both a vulner- ability and maintenance factor in models of functioning for a variety of anxiety disorders (Kashdan et al., 2006; Dymond, 2019; Van Den Hout et al., 2014). Experiential avoidance can also have negative repercussions on sustaining math anxiety (Beilock et al., 2010), but how could it be measured and captured in students dealing with math learning? Methods from cognitive network science can provide a deeper understanding of stu- dents‚Äô thought processes (D√≥czi, 2019), since mental representations of knowledge are part of a much more complex system, known as the mental lexicon. The mental lexicon can be defined as a repository of knowledge suited for the acquisition, processing, and use of all information that can be expressed via language (D√≥czi, 2019).
